Why is this?

They know as it truly is what is to be practiced and what is not to be practiced.

Having known as it truly is what is to be practiced and what is not to be practiced, they do not practice what is not to be practiced, but practice what is to be practiced. I have heard thus:
Once, the Buddha was wandering in the country of Shravasti, staying in the Jeta Grove, Anathapindika's Park.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhikshus:

A bhikshu, if he has this observation, will benefit much:ğŸ”½Do I often give rise to covetousness or do I often give rise to no covetousness?

Do I often give rise to the bonds of drowsiness and sleep or do I often give rise to no bonds of drowsiness and sleep?
Do I often give rise to conceit and arrogance or do I often give rise to no conceit and arrogance?
Do I mostly have doubts or mostly have no doubts?
Do I mostly have bodily disputes or mostly have no bodily disputes?
Do I mostly have defiled thoughts or mostly have undefiled thoughts?
Do I mostly have faith or mostly have no faith?
Do I mostly have diligence or mostly have laziness?

that bhiká¹£u, having abided in this good dharma, should seek to realize the knowledge and supernormal powers that end the contaminants.
Why is it so?
I say that one should not keep any robes, and I also say that one should keep all robes.
Why do I say that one should not keep robes?
If keeping robes increases unwholesome dharmas and diminishes wholesome dharmas, I say that such robes should not be kept.
Why do I say that one should keep robes?
If keeping robes increases wholesome dharmas and diminishes unwholesome dharmas, I say that such robes should be kept.
It is like clothes, food and drink, beds and seats, and villages and towns. I say one should not associate with all people, and I also say one should associate with all people.
Why do I say one should not associate with people?
If one associates with people, then unwholesome and unskillful dharmas increase and wholesome dharmas decline, then I say one should not associate with such people.
Why do I say one should associate with people?
If one associates with people, then wholesome dharmas increase and unwholesome and unskillful dharmas decline, then I say one should associate with such people.
They know as it truly is what is a practice to be cultivated, and what is a practice not to be cultivated.

Having known as it truly is what is a practice to be cultivated and what is a practice not to be cultivated, they do not cultivate what is a practice not to be cultivated, and they cultivate what is a practice to be cultivated. This is called a monk who observes his own mind well, knows his own mind well, and skillfully accepts and rejects.

The SÅ«tra on Attaining the Holy Life (111) The Middle Length Ä€gamas, the Forest Section, the SÅ«tra on Attaining the Holy Life, the Fifth, the Second Small Earth Fortress Recitation I have heard thus:
Once, the Buddha was wandering in Kuru, in the city of Kumbhahattha in Kuru.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:

I will teach you the Dharma, which is wonderful in the beginning, wonderful in the middle, and wonderful in the end, with its own meaning and phrasing, complete, pure, and revealing the holy life. It is called 'Attaining the Holy Life,' which can exhaust all defilements.
Listen carefully and think about it well.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us accepted the teaching and listened.
The World-Honored One said:

You should know the taints, know the causes of the arising of the taints, know the results of the taints, know the superiority of the taints, know the complete cessation of the taints, and know the path leading to the cessation of the taints.ğŸ”½You should know the perceptions, know the causes of the arising of the perceptions, know the results of the perceptions, know the superiority of the perceptions, know the complete cessation of the perceptions, and know the path leading to the cessation of the perceptions.

You should know the thoughts, know the causes of the arising of the thoughts, know the results of the thoughts, know the superiority of the thoughts, know the complete cessation of the thoughts, and know the path leading to the cessation of the thoughts.

You should know the desires, know the causes of the arising of the desires, know the results of the desires, know the superiority of the desires, know the complete cessation of the desires, and know the path leading to the cessation of the desires.

You should know the actions, know the causes of the arising of the actions, know the results of the actions, know the superiority of the actions, know the complete cessation of the actions, and know the path leading to the cessation of the actions.

You should know the suffering, know the causes of the arising of the suffering, know the results of the suffering, know the superiority of the suffering, know the complete cessation of the suffering, and know the path leading to the cessation of the suffering.
What is knowledge of the taints?
There are three taints:
the taint of sensual desire, the taint of existence, and the taint of ignorance. This is called knowledge of the taints.
What is knowledge of the arising of the taints?
It is ignorance.
Because of ignorance, the taints arise. This is called knowledge of the arising of the taints.
What is knowledge of the results of the taints?
Those who are bound by ignorance are soaked by the taints. Because of this, they experience results, whether in a good realm or a bad realm. This is called knowledge of the results of the taints.
What is knowledge of the superiority of the taints?

Some taints lead to rebirth in hell, some taints lead to rebirth as an animal, some taints lead to rebirth as a hungry ghost, some taints lead to rebirth in the heavens, and some taints lead to rebirth among humans. This is called knowledge of the superiority of the taints.
What is knowledge of the cessation of the taints?
When ignorance ceases, the taints also cease. This is called knowledge of the cessation of the taints.
What is knowledge of the path to the cessation of the taints?
It refers to the eightfold noble path, namely right view up to right concentration, which are eight. This is called knowing the path to the cessation of defilements.

If a monk knows defilements like this, knows the cause of the arising of defilements, knows the experience of the results of defilements, knows the superiority of defilements, knows the complete cessation of defilements, and knows the path to the cessation of defilements, this is called penetrating the holy life, able to end all defilements.
What is called knowing feeling?
It refers to the three feelings:
pleasant feeling, painful feeling, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. This is called knowing feeling.
What is called knowing the cause of the arising of feeling?
It refers to contact.
Because of contact, there is feeling. This is called knowing the cause of the arising of feeling.
What is called knowing the result of feeling?
It refers to craving.
Craving is the result of feeling. This is called knowing the result of feeling.
What is called knowing the superiority of feeling?

It is said that a monk, when experiencing a pleasant feeling, knows he is experiencing a pleasant feeling; when experiencing an unpleasant feeling, he knows he is experiencing an unpleasant feeling; when experiencing a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, he knows he is experiencing a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling. With a pleasant body, unpleasant body, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant body, a pleasant mind, unpleasant mind, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant mind, a pleasant food, unpleasant food, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant food, a pleasant absence of food, unpleasant absence of food, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant absence of food, a pleasant desire, unpleasant desire, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant desire, a pleasant absence of desire, unpleasant absence of desire, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant absence of desire, when experiencing a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant absence of desire, he knows he is experiencing a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant absence of desire. This is called knowing the superiority of feelings.
What is the knowledge of the cessation of feelings?
It is that with the cessation of contact, feeling also ceases. This is called the knowledge of the cessation of feelings.
What is the knowledge of the path leading to the cessation of feelings?
It is the noble eightfold path, from right view to right concentration, making eight. This is called the knowledge of the path leading to the cessation of feelings.

If a monk knows feeling, knows the cause of the arising of feeling, knows the result of feeling, knows the satisfaction and danger in feeling, and knows the escape from feeling, then he is said to have penetrated the holy life and can end all feelings.
What is knowing perception?
There are four kinds of perception.
A monk knows small perception, knows great perception, knows immeasurable perception, and knows the perception of the sphere of nothingness. This is called knowing perception.
What is knowing the cause of the arising of perception?
It is contact.
Dependent on contact, there is perception. This is called knowing the cause of the arising of perception.
What is knowing the result of perception?
It is speech.
According to one's perception, one speaks. This is called knowing the result of perception.
What is knowing the satisfaction and danger in perception?
It means that there are thoughts of form, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects. This is called knowing the superiority of thoughts.
How does one know the cessation of thoughts?
It means that when the sense pleasures cease, thoughts cease. This is called knowing the cessation of thoughts.
How does one know the path to the cessation of thoughts?
It means the eightfold noble path, from right view to right concentration, making eight. This is called knowing the path to the cessation of thoughts.

If a monk knows thoughts in this way, knows the cause of the arising of thoughts, knows the result of thoughts, knows the superiority of thoughts, knows the cessation of thoughts, and knows the path to the cessation of thoughts, this is called penetrating the holy life, able to end all thoughts.
How does one know desire?
It means there are five kinds of desirable, delightful, beautiful, desirable, and very enjoyable sense pleasures.
What are the five?
The eye knows forms, the ear knows sounds, the nose knows smells, the tongue knows tastes, the body knows tactile objects, this is called knowing desire.
What is knowing the cause of the arising of desire?
It is contact.
Because of contact, desire arises, this is called knowing the cause of the arising of desire.
What is knowing the result of desire?

It is according to the kind of desire one delights in and clings to, one dwells there, and because of this one experiences the result, whether in a place of blessings, a place of no blessings, or a place of imperturbability, this is called knowing the result of desire.
What is knowing the superiority of desire?

There are desires for forms, there are desires for sounds, there are desires for smells, there are desires for tastes, there are desires for tactile objects, this is called knowing the superiority of desire.
What is knowing the cessation of desire?
It is the cessation of contact, then desire ceases, this is called knowing the cessation of desire.
What is knowing the path to the cessation of desire?
Namely, the eightfold noble path, right view up to right concentration, making eight. This is called knowing the path to the cessation of desire.

If a bhiká¹£u knows desire like this, knows the cause of the arising of desire, knows the retribution of experiencing desire, knows the superiority of desire, knows the complete cessation of desire, and knows the path to the cessation of desire, this is called penetrating the holy life, able to end all desires.
What is called knowing karma?
There are two kinds of karma:
